simulated_ratings.title: Blade Runner (1982)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moody, rain-soaked sci‑fi noir with existential edge—right up my alley.

simulated_ratings.title: 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Majestic and hypnotic, but the chill kept me at arm’s length—admiration over attachment.

simulated_ratings.title: Stalker (1979)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Haunting and contemplative, rewarding patience but a bit too austere for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Solaris (1972)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Introspective space psychodrama that intrigues more than it moves me.

simulated_ratings.title: Children of Men (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gritty near‑future despair with bursts of urgency

simulated_ratings.title: Annihilation (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Uncanny vibes and ideas I like, though the modern gloss dulls the impact.

simulated_ratings.title: The Thing (1982)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Paranoia and creature dread work, even if the shock factor wears thin for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Alien (1979)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tense, claustrophobic slow‑burn that nails mood and menace.

simulated_ratings.title: The Shining (1980)
simulated_ratings.feeling: I dig the icy unease and imagery, even if it keeps me cold.

simulated_ratings.title: Se7en (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grim and methodical

simulated_ratings.title: Zodiac (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Immersive, procedural obsession done with admirable restraint.

simulated_ratings.title: The Conversation (1974)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Paranoid, morally gnawing slow‑burn that hits my sweet spot.

simulated_ratings.title: Chinatown (1974)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sun‑bleached noir corruption that I respect more than I love.

simulated_ratings.title: Memories of Murder (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleak investigation with character bite

simulated_ratings.title: The Vanishing (1988)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Taut and unsettling, though its clinical chill keeps me from fully sinking in.

simulated_ratings.title: Heat (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cat‑and‑mouse professionalism is engaging, if a touch overblown.

simulated_ratings.title: A Scanner Darkly (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Paranoid futurism and identity slippage I enjoy, even if it meanders.

simulated_ratings.title: Coherence (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever dinner‑party mindwarp—lean, nifty, not quite lingering.

simulated_ratings.title: Primer (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Knotty and cerebral in a way I enjoy, if a bit too hermetic.

simulated_ratings.title: Timecrimes (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Fun looping puzzle, but it plays more clever than affecting.

simulated_ratings.title: The Lives of Others (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quiet surveillance drama with a moral ache that lands.

simulated_ratings.title: Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Dry, meticulous spycraft I appreciate more than I feel.

simulated_ratings.title: Paths of Glory (1957)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sharp anti‑war indictment—clear, forceful, if somewhat didactic.

simulated_ratings.title: Come and See (1985)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Devastating and hallucinatory

simulated_ratings.title: The Hunt for Red October (1990)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Competent cold‑war chess, a bit too polished to grip me.

simulated_ratings.title: Fargo (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleakly funny crime spiral—smart, but the whimsy doesn’t fully land for me.

simulated_ratings.title: In Bruges (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Wordy, guilt‑soaked banter that amuses in parts but feels arch.

simulated_ratings.title: The Lobster (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Deadpan dystopia with ideas I admire, tone keeps me at a distance.

simulated_ratings.title: The Thin Blue Line (1988)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Stylish true‑crime inquiry that sharpens outrage without grandstanding.

simulated_ratings.title: Mulholland Drive (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Dreamlike Hollywood noir—seductive and unsettling, mood over meaning.

simulated_ratings.title: Le Samouraï (1967)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cool, minimalist hit-man ritual that scratches my austere-noir itch.

simulated_ratings.title: The Parallax View (1974)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Paranoid conspiracy machine—grim, methodical, right up my alley.

simulated_ratings.title: Blow Out (1981)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Taut and stylish, though De Palma’s flourishes keep me a step removed.

simulated_ratings.title: The Manchurian Candidate (1962)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Ice-cold political paranoia that still bites.

simulated_ratings.title: Army of Shadows (1969)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Somber resistance fatalism—quietly crushing.

simulated_ratings.title: The Battle of Algiers (1966)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Vivid, morally thorny street-level warfare that grips without sentiment.

simulated_ratings.title: The Thin Red Line (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lyrical war reverie I admire more than I feel.

simulated_ratings.title: L.A. Confidential (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slick, knotty noir—engaging, if a bit too polished to haunt.

simulated_ratings.title: Dark City (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Shadow-soaked sci-fi noir with a mood I sink into.

simulated_ratings.title: Gattaca (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Elegant, restrained dystopia—smart, a touch too pristine.

simulated_ratings.title: 12 Monkeys (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grim, looping fever-dream that lands its dread.

simulated_ratings.title: Her (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tender tech romance whose glossy sentiment keeps me at arm’s length.

simulated_ratings.title: Moon (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quiet, claustrophobic ethics-in-space that I appreciate.

simulated_ratings.title: Under the Skin (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Intimate, opaque longing—evocative but emotionally distant for me.

simulated_ratings.title: The City of Lost Children (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Baroque, surreal clockwork—imagination and gloom in a satisfying blend.

simulated_ratings.title: Videodrome (1983)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Flesh, media, and mind-warp—paranoid provocation that sticks.

simulated_ratings.title: The Wicker Man (1973)

simulated_ratings.title: Don't Look Now (1973)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grief-soaked dread—hypnotic tone, cool to the touch.

simulated_ratings.title: The Innocents (1961)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Elegant, chilly ghost story whose restraint I respect.

simulated_ratings.title: Network (1976)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Acidic media satire—sharp, if a bit on-the-nose.

simulated_ratings.title: In the Loop (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Caustic bureaucratic banter that amuses more than it lands.

simulated_ratings.title: The Death of Stalin (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Deadpan power farce—funny in parts, ultimately a little glib for me.

simulated_ratings.title: After Hours (1985)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Urban nightmare screwball—anxious, amusing, pleasantly mean.

simulated_ratings.title: The Truman Show (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever media-prison fable—winsome, a shade too tidy.

simulated_ratings.title: The Fog of War (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cool, incisive reckoning that sharpens moral unease.

simulated_ratings.title: The Act of Killing (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Chilling, surreal self-incrimination that burrows under the skin.

simulated_ratings.title: The Insider (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sober corporate crusade—procedural intensity with real moral weight.

recommended_movies: The Spy Who Came in from the Cold (1965)

simulated_ratings.title: The Night of the Hunter (1955)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Haunting, expressionist fairy‑tale noir—chilly menace that lingers.

simulated_ratings.title: Rififi (1955)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Methodical heist mechanics and grim fallout—cold‑blooded clockwork I savor.

simulated_ratings.title: Out of the Past (1947)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Misty fatalism and hard‑edged seduction—classic noir mood I sink into.

simulated_ratings.title: Kiss Me Deadly (1955)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Paranoid, apocalyptic noir with a nasty pulse—right up my alley.

simulated_ratings.title: The Long Goodbye (1973)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Languid, ironic Marlowe—smart, a bit too arch for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Le Cercle Rouge (1970)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cool, meticulous heist fatalism—spare and absorbing, my tempo.

simulated_ratings.feeling: Neon professionalism and doomed resolve—moody crime I relish.

simulated_ratings.feeling: Sleek nocturnal cat‑and‑mouse—engaging, a shade too polished.

simulated_ratings.title: The French Connection (1971)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gritty, relentless street‑level pursuit—procedural intensity that lands.

simulated_ratings.title: The Spy Who Came in from the Cold (1965)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Ice‑cold, morally murky spycraft—dry in a way I savor.

simulated_ratings.title: The Day of the Jackal (1973)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clinical assassination procedural—taut, unsentimental, right up my street.

simulated_ratings.feeling: Political outrage channeled into tense, methodical thriller—grimly gripping.

simulated_ratings.title: All the President's Men (1976)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sober, meticulous newsroom grind—procedural satisfaction without grandstanding.

simulated_ratings.title: High and Low (1963)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moral pressure‑cooker turning into procedural dread—precise and absorbing.

simulated_ratings.title: Seconds (1966)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Identity paranoia and body‑horror unease—bleak, chilling, my kind of nightmare.

simulated_ratings.title: Alphaville (1965)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Deadpan sci‑fi noir that intrigues more than it moves me.

simulated_ratings.title: Strange Days (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Paranoid near‑future noir—nifty ideas, slickness blunts the impact.

simulated_ratings.title: The Andromeda Strain (1971)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clinical, methodical sci‑fi crisis—coolly engaging if a bit sterile.

simulated_ratings.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Hypnotic future‑noir—gorgeous mood, a shade too pristine to fully haunt.

simulated_ratings.title: The Haunting (1963)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Elegant, restrained hauntings—icy dread I respect more than I feel.

simulated_ratings.title: The Devil's Backbone (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Ghost story with wartime melancholy—effective, a touch sentimental for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Possession (1981)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Fevered marital breakdown into surreal horror—unnerving in the best way.

simulated_ratings.title: Cure (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Hypnotic, minimalist dread—serial‑mystery malaise that gets under my skin.

simulated_ratings.title: Blue Velvet (1986)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sunlit rot and nightmarish desire—Lynchian unease I’m happy to marinate in.

simulated_ratings.title: Delicatessen (1991)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Macabre whimsy and post‑apocalyptic gloom—baroque clockwork I enjoy.

simulated_ratings.title: In the Mood for Love (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sumptuous restraint and longing—admire the mood more than I’m moved.

simulated_ratings.title: The Terminator (1984)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lean, relentless techno‑noir—grim momentum that works for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Caché (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cool surveillance dread with moral splinters—quietly unnerving.

simulated_ratings.title: The Silence of the Lambs (1991)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Chilly, methodical cat‑and‑mouse with psychological bite I can sink into.

simulated_ratings.title: No Country for Old Men (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleak, relentless fate‑driven pursuit—cold, gripping, my tempo.

simulated_ratings.title: Sicario (2015)

simulated_ratings.title: Prisoners (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grimy moral maze and procedural dread that hang heavy without catharsis.

simulated_ratings.title: Nightcrawler (2014)

simulated_ratings.title: Michael Clayton (2007)

simulated_ratings.title: Wind River (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Stark procedural in the snow that works, even if its bluntness shows.

simulated_ratings.feeling: Lean, sardonic 70s procedural—taut clockwork that satisfies.

simulated_ratings.title: Touch of Evil (1958)
